sections.title: Understanding FRC Sensors
sections.content: Sensors provide feedback about your robot's position, movement, and environment. Understanding how to use sensors effectively is crucial for creating autonomous behaviors and precise robot control.

sections.title: Common FRC Sensors
items: Encoders: Measure motor rotation and distance traveled
Limit Switches: Detect when mechanisms reach end positions
Color Sensors: Detect game elements and field features
sections.subtitle: FRC robots typically use these sensors:

sections.title: Encoders
sections.content: Encoders are the most common sensors in FRC. They measure how much a motor has rotated, allowing you to track position, speed, and distance traveled.

sections.title: Basic Encoder Implementation
Gyroscopes
sections.content: Gyroscopes measure the robot's orientation and rotation rate. They're essential for maintaining straight paths and executing precise turns.

sections.title: Gyroscope Implementation
Limit Switches
sections.content: Limit switches are simple sensors that detect when mechanisms reach their end positions. They're essential for safety and precise positioning.

sections.title: Limit Switch Implementation
Potentiometers
sections.content: Potentiometers measure angular position and are commonly used for arms and other rotating mechanisms. They provide continuous position feedback.

sections.title: Potentiometer Implementation
Ultrasonic Sensors
sections.content: Ultrasonic sensors measure distance to objects by sending sound waves and measuring the time for them to return. They're useful for detecting game elements and avoiding obstacles.

sections.title: Ultrasonic Sensor Implementation
Sensor Integration
sections.content: Combining multiple sensors provides comprehensive feedback about your robot's state. This enables more sophisticated autonomous behaviors and precise control.

sections.title: Integrated Sensor System
Sensor Best Practices
items: Calibrate sensors: Always calibrate sensors before use
Handle sensor failures: Implement fallback behaviors when sensors fail
Filter noisy data: Use averaging or filtering for stable readings
Validate sensor data: Check for reasonable values before using data
Update frequently: Read sensors every robot loop for responsive control
Document sensor setup: Keep records of sensor configurations and calibrations
